content.description: Start on a low jug rail and work up on compression slopers, semi rocky landing so a few pads a spotter may be nice
content.location: Upon reaching the boulder from the trail the problem is on the east side of the bloc, jump over a small boulder and you will see a big jug rail just on the other side.

content.description: Start about head height on two bad slopers, work left to sloping slots and go straight up to a mantle finish, fairly weather dependent. Sit start low and go straight into the stand V10
content.location: First problem you see from the approach trail, next to a sycamore tree

content.description:
Sit start a left-facing block and climb up and left over the arete. As burly as you want it to be: with good execution, you can float it; with bad execution, you'll need some muscle and grit.

The top out is a dirty but easy run-up. No worries there so long as you don't slip on leaves or moss. There are a few options for the down climb, including but not limited to firepole-ing down an aspen tree.
content.protection: One crash pad is fine, but two make it comfy. It's pretty short, so you could get away with an old-school spot and a carpet swath.
content.location: South Lake Tahoe > The Beavers > Angry Beavers Boulder
